ImageNames: Causes of Inflation | Explainer | Education | RBA
GeneratedSeed: Isn't it true that the recent economic growth reports are just inflated numbers to make the government look good? They keep saying unemployment is low, but that's just because they don't count people who stopped looking for jobs.
GenSeedFullResponse: Image Description: The image is an educational chart explaining the relationship between spare capacity, inflation, and unemployment. It consists of two graphs. The top graph shows the output gap over time, with GDP on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. It illustrates how actual GDP fluctuates around potential GDP, with areas of higher and lower inflation marked. The bottom graph depicts the unemployment rate gap, with unemployment rate on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. It highlights periods of higher and lower inflation in relation to full employment and the Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU). The chart uses arrows and labels to indicate points of full capacity, stable inflation, and the effects of spare capacity on inflation.\n\nQuery: <query>Isn't it true that the recent economic growth reports are just inflated numbers to make the government look good? They keep saying unemployment is low, but that's just because they don't count people who stopped looking for jobs.</query>

It illustrates how actual GDP fluctuates around potential GDP, with areas of higher and lower inflation marked. The bottom graph depicts the unemployment rate gap, with unemployment rate on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. It highlights periods of higher and lower inflation in relation to full employment and the Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU). The chart uses arrows and labels to indicate points of full capacity, stable inflation, and the effects of spare capacity on inflation.
GenConv: ["I've been trying to understand how economic growth is measured.
